{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = H6K |image = KawanishiH6K.jpg |caption = }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type = Patrol flying boat |manufacturer = [[Kawanishi Aircraft Company|Kawanishi]] |designer = |first flight = 14 July 1936 |introduced = January [[1938 in aviation|1938]] |retired = [[1945 in aviation|1945]] (Japan) |status = |primary user = [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service|IJN Air Service]] |more users = |produced = |number built = 215{{harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=307.}} |unit cost = |developed from = [[Kawanishi H3K]] |variants with their own articles = }} |} The '''Kawanishi H6K''' was an [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] [[flying boat]] produced by the [[Kawanishi Aircraft Company]] and used during [[World War II]] for [[maritime patrol]] duties. The [[World War II Allied names for Japanese aircraft|Allied reporting name]] for the type was '''Mavis'''; the Navy designation was {{nihongo|"Type 97 Large Flying Boat"|九七式大型飛行艇}}. ==Design and development== [[File:Kawanishi H6K Type 97 Transport Flying Boat Mavis H6K-16s.jpg|thumb|left|An H6K suffering from an engine fire descending.]] The aircraft was designed in response to a Navy requirement of 1934 for a long range flying boat and incorporated knowledge gleaned by a Kawanishi team that visited the [[Short Brothers]] factory in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], at that time one of the world's leading producers of flying boats, and from building the [[Kawanishi H3K]], a license-built, enlarged version of the [[Short Rangoon]].{{Harvnb|Air International|December 1985|p=294.}} The '''Type S''', as Kawanishi called it, was a large, four-engine [[monoplane]] with [[twin tail]]s, and a hull suspended beneath the [[parasol wing]] by a network of struts. Three [[prototype]]s were constructed, each one making gradual refinements to the machine's handling both in the water and in the air, and finally fitting more powerful engines. The first of these flew on 14 July 1936 and was originally designated '''Navy Type 97 Flying Boat''', later '''H6K'''. Eventually, 217 would be built.{{Harvnb|Green|1972|p=129.}} ==Operational history== H6Ks were deployed from 1938 onwards, first seeing service in the [[Sino-Japanese War (1937-1945)|Sino-Japanese War]] and were in widespread use by the time the full-scale [[Pacific War]] erupted, in 1942. At that time of the war, four ''[[Kōkūtai]]'' (Air Groups) operated a total of 66 H6K4s.{{Harvnb|Green|1972|p=128.}} The type had some success over [[South East Asia]] and the [[South West Pacific]]. H6Ks had excellent endurance, being able to undertake 24-hour patrols, and were often used for long-range reconnaissance and bombing missions. From bases in the [[Dutch East Indies]], they were able to undertake missions over a large portion of [[Australia]]. However, the H6K became vulnerable to a newer generation of heavier armed and faster [[fighter aircraft|fighter]]s. It continued in service throughout the war, in areas where the risk of interception was low. In front-line service, it was replaced by the [[Kawanishi H8K]]. ==Variants== [[File:Kawanishi H6K Type 97 Transport Flying Boat Mavis H6K-8s.jpg|thumb|right|An H6K2-L Navy Transport Flying Boat Type 97]] ; H6K1 :Evaluation [[prototype]]s with four [[Nakajima Hikari]] 2 engines, 4 built. ; H6K1 (Navy Flying Boat Type 97 Model 1) :Prototypes with 746 kW 1,000 hp [[Mitsubishi Kinsei]] 43 Engines, 3 converted from the original H6K1 prototypes. ; H6K2 Model 11 :First production model. Includes two H6K2-L officer transport modification, 10 built. ; H6K2-L (Navy Transport Flying Boat Type 97) :Unarmed transport version of H6K2 powered by Mitsubishi Kinsei 43 engines, 16 built. ; H6K3 Model 21 :Modified transport version of H6K2 for VIPs and high-ranking officers, 2 built. ; H6K4 Model 22 :Major production version, modified H6K2 with revised weapons, some with 694 kW (930 hp) Mitsubishi Kinsei 46 engines. Fuel capacity increased from 7,764 L (1,708 Imp gal) to 13,410 L (2,950 Imp gal). Includes two H6K4-L transport versions, 100 to 127 (if other numbers are all correct) built. ; H6K4-L :Transport version of H6K4, similar to H6K2-L, but with Mitsubishi Kinsei 46 engines, 20 built and another two converted from the H6K4. ; H6K5 Model 23 :Fitted with 969 kW (1,300 hp) Mitsubishi Kinsei 51 or 53 engines and new upper turret replacing the open position, 36 built. ==Operators== [[File:H6K in Soerabaja.jpg|thumb|[[Royal Air Force]] mechanics inspecting an H6K at [[Soerabaja]], [[Java]], prior to a test flight in January 1946. Note the [[Flag of Indonesia|Indonesia flag]] added by nationalists and the additional [[Flag of the Kingdom of the Netherlands|blue band]] added to the fuselage marking by the Dutch]] ;{{IDN}} *[[Indonesian Air Force|Air Service Volunteer Corps]] - A single H6K5 flying boat was restored to flight by Indonesian forces during the [[Indonesian National Revolution|Indonesian War of Independence]].''Air Enthusiast Quarterley'' 1976, p. 156. ;{{JPN}} * [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] * [[Imperial Japanese Airways]] : Used on the routes [[Yokohama]]-[[Saipan]]-[[Koror]] ([[Palau]])-[[Timor]], [[Saigon]]-[[Bangkok]] and [[Saipan]]-[[Chuuk Lagoon|Truk]]-[[Pohnpei|Ponape]]-[[Jaluit]].{{harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=306.}} ==Specifications (H6K4)== {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?= plane |jet or prop?= prop |ref= ''Warplanes of the Second World War, Volume Five: Flying Boats'';
